title: Will Jacob Zuma cease to be president of South Africa before 1 January 2017?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The man has all but survived the year.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Time is passing and the deadline is looming yet Zuma is still firmly in place.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Only if he dies of natural causes in office by that date. There is insufficient political opposition to oust him before then.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Down 2% since lightning is not likely to strike.
More confidence in last justification, downward trend, and closing window.

Affirming at 1 despite rumblings within ANC leadership committee on word of weakness of support for no-confidence motion. He appears almost certain to survive this push, and if he does , there probably won't be another one in the next few weeks.

Diffusion of responsibility if by secret ballot, wishful thinking (that the ANC can do fine with 2 more years of Zuma), infighting between ANC members, corruption, and pressure for party loyalists. Zuma will be questioned on Dec 3rd, but everything could be deferred. until next on account of the holidays. ANC could face increased pressure from the public and still hold non-consequential votes.
Down 3% since he survived the vote. Keeping it just above the consensus considering the likely/possible downgrading of debt.

Up 20% on this news: http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/anc-meeting-extended-zumas-fate-uncertain-2093875
http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-28-the-endgame-zuma-on-the-ropes-as-anc-tactical-manoeuvre-unfolds/#.WDvDP9R97iw
Zuma will fight back, of course, and getting rid of this lame duck president and his entourage won't be without problems, but it's Belshazzar's Feast time, I suspect. http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-27-analysis-should-zuma-lose-the-dominoes-would-fall/#.WDu-sNR97iw
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Reduced because of the march of time. 
Even so, the pressure remains - http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/anc-turns-on-zuma-20161126
Zuma, on the other hand, has more lives than a cat, dodging every bullet directed at him.

"President Jacob Zumaâ€™s future as ANC president was left hanging by a thread after Tourism Minister Derek Hanekom stunned Zuma and his backers when he tabled a motion for him to step down at the national executive committee (NEC) meeting yesterday." http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/anc-turns-on-zuma-20161126
The interesting part is that there is lobbying for a secret ballot, which could spell doom for Teflon Jake as there would be less fear of backlash. Without the closed shop vote, dozens of members will conveniently absent themselves - as happened with the most recent no-confidence motion - but they might show up if they can vote without reprisals.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

South Africa's Jacob Zuma defeats no-confidence vote in parliament
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/south-africas-jacob-zuma-defeats-no-confidence-vote-in-parliament/articleshow/55359293.cms
He won the vote of No Confidence convincingly
Down 25% to be closer to the consensus for awhile.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
He faces another vote of no confidence in the next weeks. He might well loose given the recent corruption report release

One could venture to say that the local grroundswell that "Zuma must resign" is  also being facilitated by non SAF interests who are  meddling in the internal affairs of a soverign nation.  The Mandela Foundation is a major local actor. But remember that Mandela was longtime CIA and Kremlin asset and Zuma had his back.m

No change to forecast. Just trying to wrap my head around the latest developments.
Madonsela report paints a grim picture for Zupta and his cronies: http://qz.com/825789/state-capture-jacob-zuma-the-guptas-and-corruption-in-south-africa/ But, as the former Public Protector has said, she "should have been harder on Zuma", and her released findings leave some wiggle room for the accused.
Vote of no-confidence tabled for Nov 10: http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-03-explainer-misconceptions-about-a-no-confidence-vote/#.WB53yNR97iw It's the third this year, and as the vote will be open rather than secret there's no great confidence that Zuma will be asked to resign.
However, ANC chief whip Jackson Mthembu's call for the entire NEC to step down is resounding: https://www.enca.com/south-africa/anc-nec-called-to-resign If Gordhan supporter CyrilRamaphosa can be emboldened to vote against his boss - possibly a good political move - this could be a done deal.
Assuming, though, that the no-confidence motion fails, the next week or two may decide this question one way or another. The next step is a judicial inquiry scheduled for early December, during which a lot of dirty laundry will be aired. It's just possible that more than a few stalwarts may see this as cancerous for the ANC and quietly urge Zuma to resign with what's left of his dignity.

According to a report on BBC Newshour yesterday, there is increasing pressure for him to step down because of the corruption scandal involving Ajay Gupta and his family, as detailed in the report "State Capture," (http://qz.com/825789/state-capture-jacob-zuma-the-guptas-and-corruption-in-south-africa/)
Jumping up to 33 percent on no-confidence vote planned for Nov 11.  Will watch politics ahead of vote to consider further increases, and will drop to 1 if he survives that vote.

The bad news is piling up at an alarming rate. In the past week alone, Zuma has lost out on the Gordhan charges and the State Capture report, The Nelson Mandela Foundation and unions representing half a million workers have called for his resignation, and thousands of protesters have clashed with police in Pretoria. The editorial cartoonists of SA are also having their say: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/02/protests-in-pretoria-as-south-africans-call-for-jacob-zuma-to-resign
According to Prince Mashele, a political analyst at Pretoria-based Centre for Politics and Research, "“I will be surprised if Zuma were to survive until January,” http://www.fin24.com/Economy/zuma-days-are-numbered-as-crisis-deepens-20161102 The same article does warn, however, that "hounding him out of office is easier said than done.”
I know the consensus on this question is very low, but Zuma is dead in the water. The only real questions are: Will he jump, or will he be pushed? And will either of those things happen before the end of the year?

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37845606
Nothing will happen, just as it has been with dizzying regularity right along.  The ANC has nobody special waiting in the wings just yet. It will take a while to groom a successor, which these days should probably entail shredding everybody's records and blowing up everybody's mobile 'phones and computers.  It is disheartening to realize that nobody learned anything from Richard Nixon's failure to destroy the tapes.

BBC (and others) report Mandela foundation demanding ouster of Zuma now is a classic example of what Lippmann and Chomsky called manufactured/manufacturing opinion link here http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37833372  but not likely to happen before close of this forecasting problem.

Time marches on.
Yet the battle rages on and there remains a strong chance the Zuma presidency will end prematurely.
Trumped up charges against Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan were withdrawn this morning in a blow to the Zuma camp.
http://www.theglobeandmail.com//news/world/abruptly-dropped-charges-against-minister-a-fresh-defeat-for-zuma/article32589827/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Though the tensions are still there, time is marching on and little of consequence is happening.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Back up to 2:1 in light of recent events. Zuma's Gordhan/Gupta dilemma has real potential to unravel his presidency, and with two months to go the timeline for a recall or resignation is still feasible. http://www.fin24.com/BizNews/how-world-sees-sa-zuma-now-increasingly-vulnerable-after-latest-bombshells-20161018
Zuma remains a wily customer, however, and getting rid of him won't be easy. I thought his recent comments about SA democracy were very interesting: http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/tell-the-world-its-democracy-zuma-to-ambassadors-20161018
Is it too much to hope that this indicates he has seen the writing on the wall? In a broader context, a Zuma resignation would have an enormous impact on what passes for democracy in Africa. Consensus is so low on this question because African presidents - Nkurunziza, Kabila, Jammeh, Mugabe, dos Santos, Idriss Deby, Afwerki etc etc - don't resign, no matter what. Zuma has the chance to make a real statement here, but will he?
Disrupting the momentum of his enemies, Team Zuma moves from one court to another, and it all buys time, link here http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/its-not-over-yet-for-zuma-20161008

This is just my initial guess, so I attach low confidence. I have been following the situation there, but have not been trying to estimate the odds before now. There are many factors to consider, but the timing is very important to me. There is no momentum to remove Zuma right now, despite the many problems (falling Rand, uni student protests demanding free education, minimum wage debates, unrest leading to vandalism, etc). The most volatile part of the situation is his problems working with Gordhan. If he does force Gordhan out before Jan '17 then this could be enough tension (via the impact on the Rand and state borrowing costs) to push the ANC to act. Everything in SA takes much longer than you expect, though, so it seems very unlikely to be possible before the end of 2016.

The endgame is in play. 
The National Prosecuting Authority is proceeding against Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan with trumped-up charges relating to his tenure as head of SARS (SA Revenue Services).
This is a high-stakes stand-off.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The current storm appears to have passed and the man is still firmly in office.
Back down 10% for passage of time (and not too much turmoil either in the streets or related to the economy).
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Sweeping radical party reform proposals, whether in themselves laudatory or not, seem to be more of a distraction than something that might be sufficient to unseat Zuma. It seems to me that given the recalcitrant nature of Zuma, either a split within the ANC ruling body (a renegade group) or wholesale withdrawal of cooperation with the ANC by society generally (grinding the economy to halt) are the two most effective strategies to remove Zuma. Left up to himself, Zuma will not resign, the ANC leadership will also not spontaneously offer up a mea culpa and resign; and any proposal that calls for such is more of a hindrance than a help to the goal of removing Zuma. To date, there are no ANC leadership renegades (or any bloc of such renegades) nor is there any news of general civil strikes or other manifestations of withdrawal of support intended to force the issue to a short term resolution.
http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/the-seven-sins-the-anc-must-fix-to-survive-20160924

There is much muttering in the ANC about Zuma, but many of the mutterers are reluctant to take any action until they are sure lots of other people will support them.  However, it is in the nature of muttering that it takes a while for its effects to spread enough to have any real-world results.  This, despite the fact that from an early age I was told that a boy's best friend is his mutter.

A few claws are out at last: http://www.timeslive.co.za/thetimes/2016/08/30/Eastern-Cape-ANC-branches-make-Zuma-must-go-call
Zuma has always been more of a puppeteer than a politician but his grip on the strings is slipping. (Is the Gupta sell-off a symptom of mounting unease?)
The ANC is holding some big meetings next month and I'm pretty sure it is considering ALL its options now. Four months to go - that's a very long time in politics.

Zuma is engaged in an awkward stand-off with his own finance minister and is attracting more criticism from within the ruling ANC. Many see Zuma as a liability and are calling on the party to ditch him.
Despite setbacks in municipal elections, the ANC doesn't seem to be in any hurry to ditch Zuma.

Reversing my call, as it appears that ANC lacks the spine to remove Zuma in wake of recent elections downturn. Zuma will go, but not until there's an unavoidable reason to dump him. Lingering rape allegations and corruption charges make such a reason quite possible, though not until next year, I suspect. 
Not prepared to completely give up on the chances of a Zuma sacking or resignation though - there are simply too many people angry and frustrated by his leadership.

ANC selects a new party leader in 2017, before the SAfrican elections in 2019.
Seems reasonable Zuma stays until new leadership is set (former wife is a possibility).

Up 10% after I thought some more about the election results. Agree that the time is short, but the economic issues probably have no chance of being addressed with Zuma in place. (Of course like Syria, no guarantee things will be better once Zuma moves on.)
I need to revisit this in the next few days, because the ANC lost big in the elections. They may want to jettison Zuma sooner than planned. But how to do it?
Election blowback? I got no good insight into this situation, but it clearly should affect his standing?
The ANC did not perform well in the 3 Aug 2016 local government elections, losing significant support in the big cities. This has renewed speculation that the party may 'recall' Jacob Zuma.

Election results not good for ANC, may put pressure on Zuma.

Reducing forecast on ANC's poor showing in municipal elections. That might seem backwards, but I suspect the party will be loathe to show further signs of weakness in the wake of those results.

South Africa’s president, Jacob Zuma, has 45 days to pay back more than $400,000 (£335,000) of public money spent refurbishing his private home, a lawyer said on Tuesday, after the constitutional court approved the sum.
Position in the party is very strong, developments need to worsen quite exceptionally before this will happen
Updating, he has too strong a hold on those who are most capable of unseating him.
He's pretty terrible, but he isn't going anywhere till election day.
No. This will be too traumatic for the ANC. Rather, they will try to reason with Zuma, and/or gradually reduce his effective powers.
There are currently rumors in SA'n papers that there is some conditional momentum to remove Zuma from office depending on the outcome of the municipal elections in August.
Down 5% to be closer to consensus. Sometimes I guess the collective is "happyish" with how things are run.

With successfully warding off the impeachment vote and it not being a politically opportune time to call an election, it looks like another scandal would need to occur for a forceful removal of Zuma. I haven't seen any indication that he will step down either. Keeping an eye on the court mandated repayment, economic factors, protests, and news sources for more scandal-relatedâ€‹ news as indicators.

(no change) No links but protests about new reporting restrictions.

I have the feeling that if Zuma is forced out in the next few months, the world's pundits will loudly proclaim their 20/20 hindsight. They'll cite the Nkandla scandal and reinstated corruption charges, the Tshwane violence and disappointing local election results, SA's growing economic and employment problems, and they may even draw parallels between Zuma's resignation and that of David Cameron. It will be seen as "bowing to the inevitable." Yeah, yeah. 
As I write this, the GJO consensus is 10%. If Zuma is still in power at the end of the year, I guess that outcome will seem pretty obvious too.
Upping the odds here in light of the HC judgment in the corruption case yesterday

An important event occurred yesterday:  The High Court in Pretoria denied Zuma's application not reinstating the 783 corruption charges that was removed by government institutions prior to his election.  It is possible that this can be appeal to higher courts, however, this strategy only delays the inevitable.  According to commentators, there is a sense that he will have his day in court.  It is said that he currently studying the ruling.   Of these charges were to return to legal system for prosecution, it is highly likely that there will be a move (if prosecution occurs) by the NEC to remove Zuma as ANC president, and consequently, removal from office of state president.

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36618354
None of this will matter until ANC start to lose elections in local constituencies.  This is scheduled for August.

Bumping up to 20 on a) failure of Zuma's appeal of court ruling allowing corruption charges against him to be reinstated (see link below) and b) escalating infighting over local elections upcoming in August.
It's all quieted down too much since March/April. I think all the steam to remove him has dissipated.

I'm not sure who might be capable of uniting the ANC and the nation, but it's becoming clear that Zuma isn't that person. Only rampant cronyism is keeping him safe, but for how much longer?
The August elections are looking increasingly grim for the ruling party, while both Standard & Poor and Moody's have threatened to downgrade the economy to junk status if things don't improve quickly. http://www.bbc.com/news/business-36443111 Factionalism is growing within the ANC and now we have rioting in the streets, reflecting the political, social and economic frustrations felt by so many South Africans. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-21/protests-rocking-south-african-capital-highlight-anc-divide
Even Zuma's loyalists might start rethinking their allegiance if the party continues to lose respect, but odds of 2:1 against seem about right for now,

http://www.politicsweb.co.za/opinion/anc-feels-the-local-poll-pressure

If ANC do badly in the August locals in Joberg and Port Liz, they may move to dump him.  Stay tuned

In a public discussion last night - 13 Jun 2016 - professor Chris Landsberg indicated that "it looks increasingly like we should be asking not if but when Zuma's term will end prematurely".

We have Local Government elections on 3 Aug 2016. The ANC are likely to maintain a public facade of unity until then, despite the rumours and leaks that abound.
If they perform poorly in the elections - ANC are expected to lose significant ground in metropolitan areas and the opposition has reasonable to good prospects in 3 Metros (NMB - Nelson Mandela Bay [formerly Port Elizabeth] Johannesburg and Tshwane [formerly Pretoria]; in addition, the opposition will retain control of Cape Town) - the ANC may reassess their leadership and 'recall' Zuma (as they did with Thabo Mbeki in 2008).

The ANC would have to get rid of him, and the party doesn't want to. Nothing short of an assassin's bullet can remove him.

National Prosecuting Authority refuses to re-instate corruption charges.  Opposition will need a successful appeal, and a failure of a possible NPA appeal to the Constitutional Court, in order to get the charges re-instated.  2016 timeframe is too short, at best.

National Prosecuting Authority has refused to reinstate the corruption charges. It will go to the Supreme Court of Appeal, then the Constitutional Court. Sounds like it will take a while to either reinstate the charges or not. I don't think Zuma is going anywhere until the ANC finds a way to replace him with someone of their liking.
Down 30% to be closer to consensus. Glad I'm not JZ's underwriter.
His party seems to be rallying around him.

Marginal move up from 5% last month. Strongmen don't leave voluntarily and so far I can only see two events could shift the balance away from Zuma in the next few months - a sharp financial downgrade, or a major loss in the August local body elections. The former may not happen if the present finance minister remains, while it's likely that the ANC will retain the majority of its supporters, with or without Zuma.

Succession talks already underway, though still (presumably) with 2019 in mind. News and opinion increasingly negative, reflecting economic forecasts. Not sure yet whether Malema's antics will help or hinder Zuma but this is looking like it might be an each-way bet by end of August. Up 3%.

rawl broke out in the South African parliament on Wednesday after security officers were ordered to forcibly remove opposition MPs from the chamber.
Several punches were thrown as members of the left-wing Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) were expelled for heckling President Jacob Zuma.
It was Mr Zuma's first appearance in parliament since two damning court rulings against him.
On Friday, a court said that Mr Zuma should be charged with corruption.

Zuma is representative of a strand of thinking within the ANC, and he still has support here (although it has lessened)
The ANC itself is trying to weather a financial and political crisis and wants to demonstrate unity (although this is also an argument for the other side; take away 'unity' and add 'completence' or somesuch)
Zuma is being advised by and siding with other international factions e.g. BRICS; it's in their interest to maintain this influence (e.g. Russian nuclear power stations deal, etc.)
South Africans are increasingly sceptical of the ANC, but there's more scepticism of 'the West', 'neoliberalism', 'white capital' and a combination of other factors that suggest that international perceptions of the country's politics may be coloured more by international and/or market frameworks than perceived political reality in South Africans.

Several factors can provide some indication of the strength or weakness of the cessation of his presidency; the upcoming municipal elections in August, potential national conventions within the ANC and how they approach the current economic and political crisis (a potent combination for sure of inevitable decline,  downgraded ratings into junk bond status for South Africa (expected to occur as the political and economic crisis deepens (including low growth projections - around 0.8% for 2016 and increasing inflation, volatility within civil society regarding the constitutional court's determination regarding violations of the constitution by both Parliament the Executive,  current mobilization within civil society to perpetually engage in protest within the country if Zuma does not resign (with the ANC-NEC currently supporting a call for him to remain and calling for unity within the party while describing the crisis as an 'imperialist plot'); an increase in the deep divide between intraparty factionalism and interparty factionalism and mass mobilization by workers, students, religious leaders, and the potential to creating a network within the international community to apply sanctions related activism and legislation aimed at stabilizing the country (destabilization seem as Zuma's continued hold on the executive and the apparatus of the state.  Additional motivating factors are the number of daily protests, strikes and violence events within civil society toward political parties (ie., members) and the state, including factionalism in general.
Starting low based upon my first and hard-learned rule of sitting heads of state: they don't go easy.
